best_practices: Use Server Components by default, only add 'use client' when hooks or events are needed
Wrap lazy-loaded components in SuspenseLoader to prevent layout shift
Apply type safety with TypeScript strict mode, avoid 'any' type
anti_patterns: Adding 'use client' to every component unnecessarily
Using early returns for loading states instead of Suspense
Skipping error handling with error.tsx for error boundaries

faq.question: What is the difference between Server and Client Components?
faq.answer: Server Components run on the server and reduce bundle size. Client Components use hooks and events. Default to Server Components.

faq.question: How do I handle loading states properly?
faq.answer: Use SuspenseLoader wrapper with useSuspenseQuery. Never use early returns as they cause layout shift.

faq.question: Can I use this with other UI libraries?
faq.answer: Yes. The principles apply to any React project. Replace shadcn/ui imports with your preferred library.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using these patterns?
faq.answer: Yes. Server Components keep sensitive logic server-side. Client components only receive rendered data.

faq.question: How do I debug issues with these patterns?
faq.answer: Check error boundaries, verify query keys match, ensure SuspenseLoader wraps suspended components, and use React DevTools.

faq.question: How does this compare to create-react-app or Vite?
faq.answer: Next.js provides server rendering and file-based routing. The data patterns differ but the component patterns are similar.
